pros: Small class size setting, and focus on real world applications.
cons: Very small space with limited parking

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: Salary is average but benefits are not bad.
cons: Managers are giving impossible deadlines to head of IT and pressure the engineers to work on the weekends to finish the projects. Most of the time there is no time for QA or basic testing. Tech stack is from decades ago.

review_title: Good for many things, but not enough to stay
pros: They have excellent employee benefits from affordable health/dental/vision, to misc. discounts, and plenty of PTO/sick time/ and days off provided by the company. You have the ability to move up, depending on your department. Depending on your preference, the smaller size of the University could be a good thing as you will be able to get close with many people here, you can rub shoulders with the right people, if you're the right person.
cons: Elitism sums it all up. Deans feel like they own the place, many have been here almost their whole life so they feel like some kind of royalty. Almost feels like they're trying to make up for some attention and prestige they didn't get to have when they were college-aged. Too bad more people can't come in and help shake up this ancient way they've adopted. They get into a comfort zone and refuse to consider change, even if it's mandatory. I've heard staff members say they're "being treated like a student", as if that's a bad thing. So they've created a divide between them and students, as if they're better than the students. This place feels like a corporation more than a college. Decisions have been made mostly on the preferences of higher ups than the needs of students, and the students feel that. Dare you ask a Dean to compromise to help another department, you will be spoken to real unpleasantly. If you try to defend yourself against them, your boss will buckle their knees to the higher up, so you lose the trade regardless, feeding these people's sense of entitlement. The University needs more uniformity on how they handle conflicts, very unprofessional at times speaking with people who claim to be professionals just because of their degrees and years working here. Unfortunately, they will continue to lose good workers because of this poor environment and culture. The time off is nice, but maybe we wouldn't want so much time off if the environment was more pleasant. Certain roles are constantly opening over and over, makes you wonder why. Also, if you don't know the right people, you will not know half of what is going on here. You have to be the right kind of person to get in the inner circle, or have been here long enough (10+years) to know the history and provide insight. The models here seem so sketchy I wouldn't be surprised if this place shuts down in the next several years. They also have no space for half the things they try to do. Students are always on each other in the lounge/study rooms, bathrooms are always full and dirty/stinky. Students seem downtrodden most days. This place needs more campus space, but they've let other colleges expand and take over all the local real estate. They try to express concern for all these things mentioned, but most of it feels fake. They had a training on diversity and inclusion and faculty made remarks during that training that confirmed for me this place will never really learn how to be inclusive. There is a high international student population too, likely because of the money they bring, which makes some of those remarks I heard during that training even more concerning. The person who made the comments was not held accountable either, so what was the point of that training?

review_title: This is an alright place to work as full-time staff.
pros: Pay is alright, 2 weeks off at the holidays that are not out of PTO are a great perk, and benefits are good.
cons: Pay could definitely be better. Upward trajectory is unlikely and is dependent on department.

review_title: Please, respect yourself and don’t take the offer. You deserve better than this.

cons: Smile and nod culture. Management needs constant validation from employees

pros: Depending on the role, able to gain experience as an international student. Great way to interact with the student body and make new friends.

cons: Limited space, rapid growth led to resources being stretched thin.

pros:
The fellow faculty was very welcoming and encouraging. The staff was very helpful. 
I appreciated the help and resources from the department during the sudden shift to an online format.

review_title: Great benefits, but doesn't make up for the rest
pros: Great benefits-- good insurance, ample vacation time, extra days off around holidays.
cons:
No sense of community whatsoever. The communication within campuses, departments and from administration down is terrible (never mind across other campuses and departments). 

There is no training, very minimal support from others, and no sense of community. Very few people are introduced upon arrival and very few are mentioned when leaving. There is a major ego problem among many faculty and staff. This isn't Harvard, and even if it was, there would still be no reason for these supreme egos. There are some great people, but they are VERY few and far between. 

As is typical with higher education, there isn't a lot of opportunity for growth or advancement.

job_title: Assistant Professor, Optometry in Worcester, MA
pros: I have been working at a new program on the Worcester campus for less than a year.  There is a lot of opportunity for growth within the program.  Recently, mid-level administration has been revamped.  Due to this there have been many improvements and I see a bright future for the program.  Upper tier management within the University is very supportive and encourages a team-driven effort toward success.  Very professional and friendly team-oriented work environment.
cons: This position is not for someone looking for an easy job where they can "coast".  Because this is a new program there is a lot of hard work involved.  Every member of the team needs to operate a peak performance all the time. Good communication is a must because of the need to create a cohesive program.  You must be a team-oriented and very self-motivated worker.

pros:
A good university that grew from being a small specialty school to now being a major center of health science education. It is one of those universities that justifies the cost because students do graduate with solid paying jobs.

Working here is enjoyable because the university does take care of its employees. The retirement benefits are awesome at 10% salary contribution automatically after your first year. Winter holidays and a week off for thanksgiving. Depending on which department you work for, you can find plenty of opportunities for advancement and getting paid to gain additional credentials.
cons: The university grew very quickly over the last few years and has outgrown itself in some ways. Not enough space in the Boston campus so a lot of focus has been put into growing the Worcester campus. The organization is heading into the right direction, but due to the growing pains the process is awkward sometimes.

pros: Diverse, interesting, driven student population. Growing organization. Financially sound. Good colleagues. Solid history. Accessible campus locations.
cons: Out of control micro-management in which the highest level of administration regularly makes decisions about day-to-day functions which they do not well understand. Highly insular leadership team. Decisions are often "penny wise pound foolish," short-sighted, and not in the best interests of students' wellbeing or success.

pros: Average salary for industry ,most  faculty are well educated and have experience teaching or have conducted research in their field.  Campus is kept clean and there are campus events on occasion.
cons: Staff are treated like the help. Staff often work overtime to accommodate faculty with no compensation. Often department heads bend the rules and make unreasonable demands. Job descriptions are vague and generic.

review_title: The right place at the right time
pros: You can really build your own role as a staff member here. The more you want to take on and contribute, the more you'll be allowed to
cons: Structure has been a bit shaken up, so if you're someone who needs a fixed definition of what your duties are and what your progression will be, you may be lost

review_title: Great for beginners but no room for growth
pros: Teamwork is highly encouraged. Emphasis on meetings with substance. You need to be able to work with faculty and staff - treating all with respect.
cons: No room for upward growth so people leave in order to have a greater experience. You will not have the opportunity to supervise, and the institution looks for that when hiring for higher positions.

review_title: A great start for the career.
pros: Everyone in the library are some of the nicest people that I've met. They're all excellent mentors, and provide me with a wealth of information.
cons: As of right now, nothing honestly stands out in my mind in particular. I've only been employed there for a few months, and so far the only challenge I've had is remembering to have my ID hanging on me at all times.

pros: Management is very willing to work with your schedule and holds weekly meetings to discuss concerns or problems you are having.
cons: Change of management occurred halfway through my employment and I felt as if many of us were left without direction for a few months.
